title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe the spatial pattern of the companies and institutions shown in the inset map using ONE of the following:

  • Agglomeration of similar economic activities.

  • Cluster or clustering of similar economic activities.

  • The concentration of similar activities along transportation routes (e.g., rivers, arterial roads).

  • There is a concentration of similar economic activities within a metropolitan area in Massachusetts.

The response correctly describes the spatial pattern of the companies and institutions shown in the inset map using ONE of the following:

  • Agglomeration of similar economic activities.

  • Cluster or clustering of similar economic activities.

  • The concentration of similar activities along transportation routes (e.g., rivers, arterial roads).

  • There is a concentration of similar economic activities within a metropolitan area in Massachusetts.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly describe the concept of a growth pole using ONE of the following:

  • A location where research, development, and/or innovation (e.g., new product or process) generate new products and/or services.

  • An institution (e.g., university, hospital, laboratory) where scientific discoveries, inventions, and/or innovations create new economic opportunities.

  • An area where new businesses start up and/or businesses locate to participate in the emerging market and/or attract investment for a new product and/or service.

  • An area where new businesses start up and/or businesses locate to access a specifically skilled or educated pool of labor.

  • An area designated by a government to facilitate economic activity for a specific purpose.

The response correctly describes the concept of a growth pole using ONE of the following:

  • A location where research, development, and/or innovation (e.g., new product or process) generate new products and/or services.

  • An institution (e.g., university, hospital, laboratory) where scientific discoveries, inventions, and/or innovations create new economic opportunities.

  • An area where new businesses start up and/or businesses locate to participate in the emerging market and/or attract investment for a new product and/or service.

  • An area where new businesses start up and/or businesses locate to access a specifically skilled or educated pool of labor.

  • An area designated by a government to facilitate economic activity for a specific purpose.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one way education infrastructure affects a region’s potential for high-technology development using ONE of the following:

  • Graduates of educational institutions, who remain in the region throughout their careers, can promote regional economic development, create innovative products or services, and/or create a source of wealth for investment in the region‘s high-technology businesses.

  • Educational institutions can develop a labor force with specialized capabilities that make an area better suited to attract high-technology businesses and/or investors from outside of the region to open new facilities and/or move existing facilities or headquarters into the region.

  • Educational institutions can sponsor research for new high-technology products and/or services which can be put into production or operation, thus creating new value, investment, and/or employment for the region’s economy.

  • Public investment in technical or specialized worker training, businesses, infrastructure, and/or equipment may divert funds away from investment in other community and social programs that support economic development.

  • Lack of educational infrastructure can negatively affect a region’s potential for high-technology development because there may not be a highly educated workforce, a specialized labor force, and/or sponsored research for high-technology products or services.

The response correctly explains one way education infrastructure affects a region’s potential for high-technology development using ONE of the following:

  • Graduates of educational institutions, who remain in the region throughout their careers, can promote regional economic development, create innovative products or services, and/or create a source of wealth for investment in the region‘s high-technology businesses.

  • Educational institutions can develop a labor force with specialized capabilities that make an area better suited to attract high-technology businesses and/or investors from outside of the region to open new facilities and/or move existing facilities or headquarters into the region.

  • Educational institutions can sponsor research for new high-technology products and/or services which can be put into production or operation, thus creating new value, investment, and/or employment for the region’s economy.

  • Public investment in technical or specialized worker training, businesses, infrastructure, and/or equipment may divert funds away from investment in other community and social programs that support economic development.

  • Lack of educational infrastructure can negatively affect a region’s potential for high-technology development because there may not be a highly educated workforce, a specialized labor force, and/or sponsored research for high-technology products or services.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain how the pattern shown on the map resembles the galactic city model using ONE of the following:

  • The region has multiple development centers (e.g., edge cities, central business districts [CBDs], suburban CBDs), which are based on a specialized product or service.

  • The pattern of business development is decentralized or spread across the region in different locations.

  • The region has a circumferential, circular, belt, or radial highway pattern associated with a galactic city’s transportation landscape.

  • The region contains several highway intersections that serve as nodes for new business districts, central business districts, or development centers.

The response correctly explains how the pattern shown on the map resembles the galactic city model ONE of the following:

  • The region has multiple development centers (e.g., edge cities, central business districts [CBDs], suburban CBDs), which are based on a specialized product or service.

  • The pattern of business development is decentralized or spread across the region in different locations.

  • The region has a circumferential, circular, belt, or radial highway pattern associated with a galactic city’s transportation landscape.

  • The region contains several highway intersections that serve as nodes for new business districts, central business districts, or development centers.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain one way local economic changes may be a result of deindustrialization using ONE of the following:

  • Deindustrialization may cause the local economy to shift from a manufacturing or industry-based economy (secondary sector) to a service and/or technology-based economy (tertiary, quaternary, or quinary sector).

  • Outsourcing of manufacturing or industrial jobs to other countries can lead to a decline in local employment levels and/or an increase in the percentage of the workforce that is unemployed or receiving unemployment benefits.

  • Increased unemployment in the central business district (CBD), declining investment, and/or declining real estate values may result from the loss of manufacturing firms, jobs, and/or services that were once supported by the former industrial economy.

  • Increases in the local use of post-Fordist methods of production (e.g., highly-specialized firms, just-in-time delivery supply chains, flexible production methods) by manufacturing firms can indicate a response to deindustrialization to make industrial production more efficient.

  • GNI per capita in the area may decrease as local people lose employment in manufacturing and/or are unable to find similar-paying jobs in another economic sector.

  • Unemployment rates or underemployment may increase as local people lose employment in manufacturing and/or are unable to find similar-paying jobs in another economic sector.

  • Cities and communities may see decreased tax revenues because of higher unemployment and/or a decrease in population that moves away to search for jobs elsewhere (e.g., backwash effects, migration).

The response correctly explains one way local economic changes may be a result of deindustrialization using ONE of the following:

  • Deindustrialization may cause the local economy to shift from a manufacturing or industry-based economy (secondary sector) to a service and/or technology-based economy (tertiary, quaternary, or quinary sector).

  • Outsourcing of manufacturing or industrial jobs to other countries can lead to a decline in local employment levels and/or an increase in the percentage of the workforce that is unemployed or receiving unemployment benefits.

  • Increased unemployment in the central business district (CBD), declining investment, and/or declining real estate values may result from the loss of manufacturing firms, jobs, and/or services that were once supported by the former industrial economy.

  • Increases in the local use of post-Fordist methods of production (e.g., highly-specialized firms, just-in-time delivery supply chains, flexible production methods) by manufacturing firms can indicate a response to deindustrialization to make industrial production more efficient.

  • GNI per capita in the area may decrease as local people lose employment in manufacturing and/or are unable to find similar-paying jobs in another economic sector.

  • Unemployment rates or underemployment may increase as local people lose employment in manufacturing and/or are unable to find similar-paying jobs in another economic sector.

  • Cities and communities may see decreased tax revenues because of higher unemployment and/or a decrease in population that moves away to search for jobs elsewhere (e.g., backwash effects, migration).

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain how the products and services listed in the table demonstrate that this economy has moved into the quaternary sector using ONE of the following:

  • The high-technology nature of the products and services listed demonstrates that the economy has moved into the quaternary sector.

  • The products and services rely on the knowledge and/or intellectual capabilities of the firms, institutions, and/or workforce that develop these advanced technologies.

  • The products and services are the outcomes of a highly educated, specialized, and/or creative class of employees who develop innovative solutions to consumer needs.

  • The products and services are dependent on the use of information technology for firms, institutions and/or the workforce to be more productive, efficient, and/or cost-effective.

The response correctly explains how the products and services listed in the table demonstrate that this economy has moved into the quaternary sector using ONE of the following:

  • The high-technology nature of the products and services listed demonstrates that the economy has moved into the quaternary sector.

  • The products and services rely on the knowledge and/or intellectual capabilities of the firms, institutions, and/or workforce that develop these advanced technologies.

  • The products and services are the outcomes of a highly educated, specialized, and/or creative class of employees who develop innovative solutions to consumer needs.

  • The products and services are dependent on the use of information technology for firms, institutions and/or the workforce to be more productive, efficient, and/or cost-effective.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly explain a possible limitation of drawing country scale conclusions from a regional scale map using ONE of the following:

  • Attempts to analyze research data from one scale of analysis to make claims about another scale of analysis may be inaccurate due to the change in scale’s effect on spatial analysis.

  • Making research assumptions from map data at one scale of analysis to make claims about another scale of analysis, may result in an incorrect calculation or an ecological fallacy due to the change in scale.

  • The region can be specialized in a sector or type of production that is different from the economic sectors or production types found in other regions of the country.

  • The region can have a long and continuing tradition of valuable or productive sectors that are very different from the changing mix of economic sectors that characterize the country’s economy.

The response correctly explains a possible limitation of drawing country scale conclusions from a regional scale map using ONE of the following:

  • Attempts to analyze research data from one scale of analysis to make claims about another scale of analysis may be inaccurate due to the change in scale’s effect on spatial analysis.

  • Making research assumptions from map data at one scale of analysis to make claims about another scale of analysis, may result in an incorrect calculation or an ecological fallacy due to the change in scale.

  • The region can be specialized in a sector or type of production that is different from the economic sectors or production types found in other regions of the country.

  • The region can have a long and continuing tradition of valuable or productive sectors that are very different from the changing mix of economic sectors that characterize the country’s economy.
